facts.text: Writ Petition No. 1 of 1960 filed under Article 32 of the Constitution for enforcement of Fundamental Rights.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL JURISDICTION Writ Petition No. 1 of 1960. Under article 32 of the Constitution of India for the enforcement of Fundamental Rights.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by Shah, J. on August 8, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: 1961. August 8. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SHAH, J.-Controls on exports and imports imposed as an emergency measure during the last war

facts.text: Imports and Exports Control Act, 1947 (Act 18 of 1947) enacted replacing Emergency Provisions Continuance Ordinance, 1946.

anchor.surface_text: lapse of the Defence of India Rules by the Emergency Provisions  Continuance  Ordinance, 1946 which was later replaced by the Imports and Exports  Control  Act,. 1947   18 of 1947 , by s. 3  of the Act, the Central Government

facts.text: Central Government issued consolidated Imports Control Order, 1955 dated December 7, 1955 imposing restrictions on import of certain goods.

anchor.surface_text: Exercising authority under s.3 of the Imports and Exports  Control  Act, 1947, the Central Government issued numberifications from time to time prohibiting, restricting or otherwise companytrolling the export and import of diverse companymodities. By a companysolidated order dated December 7, 1955, known as the Imports  Control  Order, 1955,

facts.text: Petitioners M/s. Ram Chand Jagadish Chand are a firm engaged in business as exporters and importers.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners, M s. Ram Chand Jagadish Chand are a firm engaged in. business as exporters and importers. In the period October 1958 to March 1959, the petitioners exported

facts.text: Petitioners exported Bush Shirt Cloth, Glass Nylon, Art silk Piece Goods and Superior Class Nylon to Singapore during October 1958 to March 1959 total CIF value Rs. 7,10,817/-

anchor.surface_text: In the period October 1958 to March 1959, the petitioners exported to Singapore, Bush Shirt Cloth, Glass Nylon, Art silk Piece Goods and Superior Class Nylon of the total C.I.F. value of Rs. 7,10,817/-, and relying upon cl.  2  of the Export Promotion Scheme

facts.text: Petitioners claimed entitlement to import licences for artsilk yarn of Rs. 7,07,709.55 np under Export Promotion Scheme.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners claimed that they had, pursuant to the Export Promotion Scheme, exported artsilk goods to Singapore and had earned net foreign exchange of the value of Rs. 7,07,709.55 np. and that they were entitled to import licences

facts.text: In September 1959, petitioners informed by Assistant Controller that consolidated licence for Feb-Mar 1959 granted for Rs. 3,19,354/-

anchor.surface_text: In September 1959, the petitioners were informed by the Assistant Controller of Imports and Exports that a companysolidated licence for the months of February and March, 1959 was granted to them for import of artsilk goods of the value of Rs. 3,19,354/-.

facts.text: Government of India suspended Export Promotion Scheme as from March 9, 1959 due to malpractice by importers of artsilk yarn.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the Government of India, having companye to learn of certain malpractice by the importers of artsilk yarn, while suspending the Export Promotion Scheme as from March 9, 1959,

facts.text: In May 1959, Government of India appointed Committee for verification of value of goods exported.

anchor.surface_text: announced that applications which were pending with the port licensing authorities will be scrutinised by a Committee and in May 1959, the Government of India appointed a Committee for verification of the value of good exported.

facts.text: Petitioners appeared before Committee and furnished documentary evidence supporting claim for 100% of rupee equivalent.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners appeared before the Committee and furnished documentary evidence in support of their claim for 100 of the rupee equivalent of the cloth exported.

facts.text: Committee accepted rates for Flock Printed Nylon Dyed cloth but valued Bush Shirt Cloth at Re. 1.50 np per yard of 36" width for Export Promotion Scheme.

anchor.surface_text: The Committee accepted as reasonable the rates at which the exported Flock Printed Nylon Dyed cloth was exported by the petitioners, but in their view, the rates at which ,Bush Shirt Cloth was exported companyld number be accepted as reasonable

facts.text: Controller of Licences accepted Committee's recommendation and issued import licence for Rs. 3,19,354/- only.

anchor.surface_text: The Controller of licences accepted the recommendation of the Committee and issued to the petitioners an import licence for Rs. 3,19,354/- only.

facts.text: Petitioners filed petition under Art. 32 for mandamus directing Chief Controller to grant licence for 100% value or certiorari quashing the issued licence.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners after making, an in fructuous demand for a licence for the value of the goods exported, filed this petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution for a writ or direction in the nature of mandamus directing the Chief Controller of Imports and ,Exports

facts.text: Petitioners claimed Controller arbitrarily reduced value of import licence infringing fundamental right to carry on business under Art. 19(1)(g).

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners submitted that the Controller of licences had arbitrarily reduced the value of their import licence under the Export Promotion Scheme and had thereby unlawfully infringed their fundamental right to carry on business.

facts.text: Petitioners claimed discrimination as rival importers given licences 85-100% of exports, listed 8 exporters in para 22.

anchor.surface_text: had practiced discrimination against the petitioners, because several other importers of artsilk yarn who were the petitioners rivals in trade during the identical period were given licences for amounts ranging between 85 and 100 per cent of their exports.

facts.text: Committee scrutinised cases of 1106 parties including petitioners.

anchor.surface_text: The Committee scrutinised the cases of 1106 parties including the petitioners, and the petitioners were given a, licence for Rs. 3,19,354/-, and by reducing the value of the import licence,

facts.text: Court found Committee's decision on Bush Shirt Cloth value at Re. 1.50 np/yard reasonable, no independent evidence by petitioners of higher market rate.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners have number placed before the companyrt any independent evidence to show that the current market rate of bush shirt cloth which was exported, substantially exceeded the rate of Re. 1. 50 nP. per yard of 36 width.

facts.text: Court held no discrimination under Art. 14 as other exporters' cases differed; some also reduced, others had satisfactory evidence.

anchor.surface_text: If there was evidence to show that in respect of other persons who were in the opinion of the Committee found also to have inflated the prices in the manner adopted by ,the-- petitioners and still the Controller had granted import licences

facts.text: Petition dismissed with costs; intervention application by M/s. M. Shaams and Company dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The petition fails and is dismissed with companyts. The application filed by M s. M. Shaams and Company for intervention is dismissed, because Miscellaneous Application No. 264 of 1960 which was filed by the applicants

issues.text: Whether the Controller of licences had arbitrarily reduced the value of the import licence under the Export Promotion Scheme thereby unlawfully infringing the petitioners' fundamental right to carry on business under Article 19(1)(g)?

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners submitted that the Controller of licences had arbitrarily reduced the value of their import licence under the Export Promotion Scheme and had thereby unlawfully infringed their fundamental right to carry on business.

issues.text: Whether the Controller was bound to grant import licence for the full value of the goods exported under the Export Promotion Scheme and failure to do so infringes Article 19(1)(g)?

anchor.surface_text: They also claimed that the Controller was bound to grant licence to import artsilk yarn under the Export Promotion Scheme for the full value of the goods exported by them, and in failing to do so,

issues.text: Whether the power granted under cl. 3 of the Imports Control Order, 1955 was uncanalised power in the matter of fixing percentages imposing an unreasonable restriction on the freedom to carry on business under Article 19(1)(g)?

holdings.text: The fundamental right to carry on business under Article 19(1)(g) is not absolute but subject to reasonable restrictions in the interests of the general public, including import controls under the Imports Control Order, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The fundamental right of a citizen to carry on any occupation, trade or business under Art. 19  1  g  of the Constitution is number absolute it is subject to reasonable restrictions which may be imposed by the state in the interests of the general public. The right of the State to impose companytrols in the larger interest of the general public on imports has accordingly number been denied

holdings.reasoning_summary: Existing constitutional interpretation; right qualified by public interest restrictions; prior challenges denied.

holdings.text: The power under cl. 3 of Imports Control Order, 1955 is not uncanalised or arbitrary as it is governed by Import Trade Control Policy and cls. 6-9 providing grounds and hearing opportunity.

anchor.surface_text: But the authority to grant or refuse to grant licences is conferred upon high officers of the State and the grant of licences is governed by the Import Trade Control Policy which is issued from time to time and detailed provisions are made in the Imports  Control  Order getting out the grounds

holdings.reasoning_summary: Power canalised by policy guidelines, procedural safeguards in cls. 6-9 ensure non-arbitrariness.

holdings.text: Under cl. 2 of Export Promotion Scheme (Appendix 42), the Controller has discretionary power to grant import licences 'upto' 100% of export value; no enforceable right to full 100%.

anchor.surface_text: The argument seriously canvassed by counsel for the petitioners was that relying upon cl. 2 of appendix 42 of the Import Trade Control Policy, the petitioners had exported artsilk fabrics, and had earned foreign currency, and they could not, except for good and adequate reasons,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of 'upto' confers discretion, not obligation; allows adjustment for public interest like forex position.

holdings.text: Grant of licence for Rs. 3,19,354/- not arbitrary but based on discernible principle of verifying reasonable export value amid scheme malpractices and inflated invoices.

anchor.surface_text: In granting a licence to the petitioners for Rs. 3,19,354/-, has the authority been exercised arbitrarily or is it supported by some reasonbly discernible principle? Ram Murth Sharma, Deputy Chief Controller of Imports and Exports in his affidavit stated that of the Export Promotion Scheme wrongful advantage was taken

holdings.reasoning_summary: Evidence of widespread invoice inflation (125% vs 11% wholesale rise); scrutiny of 1106 cases justified.

holdings.text: Reduction in licence value does not infringe Article 19(1)(g) as Committee's valuation of Bush Shirt Cloth at Re. 1.50 np/yard reasonable; no independent evidence of higher market rate.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners have number placed before the companyrt any independent evidence to show that the current market rate of bush shirt cloth which was exported, substantially exceeded the rate of Re. 1. 50 nP. per yard of 36 width. In the circumstances, we would number be justified in assuming that the Committee made an arbitrary decision

holdings.reasoning_summary: Petitioners' documents unsatisfactory (no linking of samples/invoices); Committee's expertise and lack of counter-evidence supports finding; prevents scheme misuse.

holdings.text: No discrimination under Article 14 as petitioners not similarly circumstanced to other exporters granted higher percentages; their evidence unsatisfactory unlike others.

anchor.surface_text: Does the fact that the petitioners have been granted licence approximately for 45 of the total value of the goods exported amount to discrimination entitling them to protection of Art. 14 of the Constitution ? Under the Export Promotion Scheme, the petitioners have exported artsilk goods of the value of Rs. 7,07,709.55.nP.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Art.14 protects against arbitrary treatment of similars; review of other cases shows different facts/evidence; no proof of identical inflation yet full grant to others.
